choices.text: 40 weeks or more from the first day of last menstrual period
42 weeks or more from the first day of last menstrual period
40 weeks or more from the last day of last menstrual period
42 weeks or more from the last day of last menstrual period

questions.text: Post-term pregnancy is defined as:
questions.solution:
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (ACOG) and the World Health organization (WHO) had defined post-term pregnancy as that lasts 42 weeks (294 days) or more from the first day of the last menstrual period.

Key Points:

  1. Postdated pregnancy is generally between 40 to 42 weeks and is considered a milder form of prolonged pregnancy.
  2. Postterm pregnancy refers to pregnancies that reach or exceed 42 weeks and are associated with significantly higher maternal and fetal risks.

questions.text: All of the following may lead to post-term pregnancy, except:
questions.solution:
Smoking usually leads to preterm birth. The suggested mechanisms include nicotine-induced vasoconstriction, carbon monoxide-induced fetal hypoxia, cadmium disruption of calcium signalling, altered steroid hormone production, disruption of prostaglandin synthesis, and changed responses to oxytocin.

Optionwise explanation:

  1. Anencephaly - True. Anencephaly is associated with post-term pregnancy due to fetal hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis dysfunction, delaying labor onset.
  2. Adrenal hypoplasia - True. Adrenal hypoplasia can cause post-term pregnancy by affecting fetal adrenal gland development, leading to insufficient cortisol production, which is necessary for labor initiation.
  3. Placental sulfatase deficiency - True. This rare genetic disorder leads to a deficiency in estrogen production from the placenta, which can delay the onset of labor and result in post-term pregnancy.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Smoking is typically associated with preterm labor rather than post-term pregnancy. It increases the risk of placental issues, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), and other complications that may result in early delivery.

questions.text: Identify the following sign seen in Intrauterine Fetal Death:
questions.solution:
Spalding sign - The irregular overlapping of cranial bones on one another is due to liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault. It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Robert's sign

  • Robert's sign is the presence of gas in the heart and great vessels of a dead fetus, typically seen on radiographic imaging. It is another indicator of intrauterine fetal death, but it does not refer to overlapping of skull bones.

b. Ball sign

  • Ball sign is associated with hydrops fetalis, where the fetus may appear as a floating "ball" in the amniotic fluid due to subcutaneous edema. It is unrelated to the overlapping of skull bones.

d. Helix sign

  • Helix sign is a helical appearance of gas in the umbilical arteries that can indicate fetal death

Key TAKEAWAY - Radiological signs in IUFD.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for postmaturity, except:
questions.solution:
• It is well established that women with low pre-pregnancy body mass index (BMI), less than 18.5 kg/m2, have a higher risk of preterm birth.
  • In contrast, women with pre-pregnancy BMI greater than 25 kg/m2 had a higher risk of post-term pregnancy.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Primigravida women

  • Primigravida women (first-time pregnant women) are more likely to experience postmaturity. Studies suggest a slightly higher incidence of prolonged pregnancies in primigravidas.

b. Lean women

  • Lean women are not generally associated with an increased risk of postmaturity. Hence, this is the correct answer to the question as an exception.

c. Previous prolonged pregnancy

  • A history of a previous prolonged pregnancy is a well-known risk factor for postmaturity. Women who have had post-term pregnancies before are more likely to experience it again.

d. Male fetus

  • Male fetuses have a slightly higher likelihood of postmaturity compared to female fetuses, making this a known risk factor.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Prolonged pregnancy is seen more in primigravidas than in multiparous women
  • Women with a previous history of prolonged pregnancy have a higher chance of recurrence.
  • Maternal obesity is also an independent predictor of post-term pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is used to grade postmaturity syndrome?
questions.solution:
• The hallmarks of the postmature infant as described by Clifford include meconium staining, loss of subcutaneous fat reserves, and skin peeling.

Option-wise explanation:

a. Clifford grading

  • Clifford grading is used to assess postmaturity syndrome by evaluating physical features of the post-term fetus, such as skin texture, peeling, and meconium staining. This makes it the correct answer.

b. Grannum grading

  • Grannum grading is used to evaluate the placenta in terms of its maturity, typically in relation to gestational age, and is not related to grading postmaturity syndrome.

c. Ballard score

  • The Ballard score is used for assessing gestational age of the newborn based on neuromuscular and physical criteria, but it does not specifically grade postmaturity syndrome.

d. APGAR score

  • The APGAR score assesses the newborn's immediate health at 1 and 5 minutes after birth, based on appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration. It is not used to grade postmaturity syndrome.
  • The total score ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating better health. A score of 7-9 is considered normal, 4-6 is moderately abnormal, and 0-3 is low.
  • The Apgar score is performed at one and five minutes after birth. The one-minute score assesses how well the baby tolerated birth, and the five-minute score assesses how well the baby is transitioning to life outside the womb. If the score is less than 7 at five minutes, the Apgar score is repeated every five minutes for up to 20 minutes.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • The infant's appearance of a postmature infant is like that of a wizened old man-long, thin, and wrinkled with reduced muscle mass and long nails at the extremities.
  • These infants are predisposed to metabolic disturbances like hypoglycemia, hypothermia, and polycythemia due to low stores of fat and glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for grading placental senescence?
questions.solution:
Option-wise explanation:

a. Clifford grading

  • Clifford grading is used for evaluating postmaturity syndrome in the fetus, not for placental senescence.

b. Grannum grading

  • Grannum grading is specifically used to assess placental senescence by grading the maturity of the placenta via ultrasound, based on the presence of calcifications and other features as pregnancy progresses. This makes it the correct answer.

c. Ballard score

  • The Ballard score is for assessing gestational age based on physical and neuromuscular characteristics, not placental senescence.

d. Silverman-Anderson score

  • The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns, not related to placental grading.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Grannum grading is used to evaluate the placenta in terms of its maturity, typically in relation to gestational age.

questions.text: Colour of amniotic fluid seen in cases of postmaturity:
questions.solution:
Greenish yellow (saffron) in post maturity

Deviation of the normal colour of liquor amnii has got clinical significance.

  • Meconium stained (green) is suggestive of fetal distress in presentations other than the breech or transverse. Depending upon the degree and duration of the distress, it may be thin or thick or pea soup (thick with flakes). Thick with the presence of flakes suggests chronic fetal distress.
  • Greenish yellow (saffron) in post maturity (OPTION A).
  • Golden colour in Rh incompatibility (OPTION B) is due to excessive hemolysis of the fetal RBC and production of excess bilirubin.
  • Dark coloured (port-wine) in concealed accidental haemorrhage (OPTION C) is due to contamination of blood.
  • Dark brown (tobacco juice) amniotic fluid is found in IUD (OPTION D). The dark colour is due to frequent presence of old HbA

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: A G1P0 at 32 weeks gestation presents with an IUFD. Which of the following radiological signs is the earliest to be demonstrated on an X-ray by?
questions.solution:
Roberts sign: Presence of gas in the fetal large vessels(earliest sign-seen 12 hours after fetal death).

Optionwise analysis:

KEY TAKEAWAY

  • Spalding's sign: Overlapping of fetal skull bones seen due to shrinkage of cerebrum after death of fetus (7 days after fetal death)
  • Ball sign: Crumpled up spine of the fetus or hyperflexion of the spine (3-4 weeks after fetal death)

questions.text:
A patient at 28 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with intrauterine fetal demise. She desires expectant management and was lost to follow up. She returns 4 weeks later, vitals Temperature 98.6 F, Pulse 88 bpm, RR 16 breaths/min, BP 110/70 mmHg. She has not yet delivered but complains of occasional spotting. CBC Report Hb 9.8 g/dl, TLC 18000/cu mm, platelet count 96000/cumm. Lab investigations show Fibrinogen level 100 mg/dl. PT INR was 1.8.
Which of the following is the most likely complication of IUFD this woman will land in?
questions.solution:
This is the most likely complication in cases of IUFD, especially with prolonged retention of the dead fetus. The lab results show thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), elevated white blood cell count, and low fibrinogen levels, which can indicate disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Therefore, consumptive coagulopathy is the most fitting answer.

Optionwise explanation:

  • Septic abortion: While this is a potential concern in cases of intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD), the patient's vital signs and lab findings do not strongly indicate an active infection.
  • Future infertility: This is not a direct complication of IUFD itself, although it can arise from complications related to the management of IUFD.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism: This is a rare complication and is more commonly associated with labor and delivery rather than a case of IUFD.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  1. In women with intrauterine fetal demise, labour usually occurs within 2 weeks.
  2. If the fetus is retained longer than 4 weeks, 25% of women can develop coagulopathy, which is manifested by decreased fibrinogen, elevated fibrin degradation products, and decreased platelets.

questions.text: All the following points may be the causes of intrauterine death, except:
questions.solution:
• Septate uterus can lead to reproductive issues such as recurrent pregnancy loss or preterm birth, it is not directly linked to IUFD. It is less likely to cause intrauterine fetal death compared to the other options
  • Septate uterus is considered the commonest uterine anomaly and it may lead to an increased rate of pregnancy loss (spontaneous abortion).

Optionwise explanation:

  • Blood group incompatibility: This condition, such as Rh incompatibility, can lead to hemolytic disease of the fetus, resulting in anemia and potentially causing IUFD.
  • Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy: Conditions like preeclampsia and eclampsia can impair placental blood flow and oxygen delivery to the fetus, leading to IUFD.
  • Intrauterine infections: Infections such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), syphilis, or listeriosis can directly impact fetal health and can lead to IUFD.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Fetal death in utero (FDIU), also known as intrauterine death (IUD), is the term used when the death of a fetus occurs after the 20th week of pregnancy. Prior to this, it is considered a miscarriage.

The maternal aetiologies of IUD include:

  • gestational hypertension
  • blood group incompatibility
  • intrauterine infections .

questions.text: All of the following are benefits of transverse abdominal incisions over vertical incisions, except:
questions.solution:
• Transverse incisions follow Langer lines of skin tension, and superior cosmetic results compared with vertical incisions can be achieved.
  • Additionally, decreased rates of postoperative pain, fascial wound dehiscence, and incisional hernia compared with vertical entry are benefits.
  • Neurovascular structures, which include the ilioinguinal and iliohypogastric nerves and superficial and inferior epigastric vessels, are often encountered with transverse incisions.
  • Vertical incisions may involve less blood loss than transverse incisions because they provide quicker access to the abdominal cavity, which can be crucial in emergency situations

Option-wise explanation:

a. Decreased postoperative pain

  • Explanation: Transverse incisions are associated with less post-operative pain compared to vertical incisions, as they cut through fewer muscle fibers and nerves.

b. Superior cosmetic results

  • Explanation: Transverse incisions tend to heal with a more aesthetically pleasing scar, as the incision line is often hidden in the natural folds of the abdomen.

c. Lesser chance of abdominal hernia

  • Explanation: The risk of incisional hernia is lower with transverse incisions because they provide better structural integrity, as the incision follows the natural direction of muscle fibers.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: Which of the following incisions requires isolation & separate ligation of the inferior epigastric arteries?
questions.solution:
The Maylard incision differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.

It is technically more difficult due to its required isolation and ligation of the inferior epigastric arteries, which lie lateral to these muscle bellies.

Option-wise Explanation:

a. Midline vertical:
False. A midline vertical incision does not require isolation and separate ligation of the inferior epigastric arteries. This incision typically runs along the midline of the abdomen, allowing for easy access without the need for significant vascular manipulation

b. Paramedian vertical:
False. Similar to the midline incision, a paramedian vertical incision is made off the midline but does not generally necessitate the isolation or ligation of the inferior epigastric arteries. It avoids major vascular structures by staying lateral to them.

d. Pfannenstiel:
False. The Pfannensteil incision is a transverse incision made just above the pubic symphysis. It does not require isolation and separate ligation of the inferior epigastric arteries because it is made subcutaneously and typically avoids major vascular structures.

KEY TAKEAWAY: The Maylard incision is the only incision listed that requires isolation and separate ligation of the inferior epigastric arteries

choices.text: Fetal scalp visible without separating the labia
Fetal skull has reached the perineum
Sagittal suture is in AP diameter

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of outlet forceps criteria?
questions.solution:
This is not a criterion for outlet forceps. Outlet forceps are typically used when the fetal head is in the occipitoanterior position or can be rotated to that position, but the rotation required for the outlet is generally less than 45 degrees. Greater rotation would typically require a different type of forceps or intervention

Option-wise Explanation:

a. Fetal scalp visible without separating the labia:
True. This is one of the criteria for outlet forceps. The fetal scalp should be visible at the vaginal introitus without needing to separate the labia, indicating that the fetal head is low in the birth canal.

b. Fetal skull has reached the perineum:
True. This is also a criterion for outlet forceps. The fetal skull must be at the perineum (the area between the vagina and the anus), indicating that it is ready to be delivered.

d. Sagittal suture is in AP diameter

  • True. This is one of the criteria for outlet forceps.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: Higher rates of failure with assisted vaginal birth are associated with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
This position is favourable for delivery and is associated with lower failure rates in assisted vaginal births. Thus, it does not contribute to higher failure rates.

Option-wise Explanation:

  1. Maternal BMI >30: Higher maternal BMI is associated with increased complications, leading to a higher failure rate in assisted vaginal births.
  2. Estimated fetal weight >4kg: Larger fetal weight is a significant risk factor for complications during delivery, often resulting in assisted vaginal birth failures.
  3. Short maternal stature: Short stature can result in anatomical limitations, contributing to higher rates of assisted vaginal birth failure.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Higher rates of failure are associated with assisted vaginal birth are seen with:

  • maternal BMI greater than 30
  • short maternal stature
  • estimated fetal weight of greater than 4 kg or a clinically big baby
  • head circumference above the 95th percentile
  • occipito-posterior position
  • midpelvic birth or when one-fifth of the head is palpable per abdomen

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 26, Assisted Vaginal Birth

questions.text: Identify this recently introduced device for assisted vaginal birth:
questions.solution:
Other options:

a. Kiwi Omnicup: A vacuum extraction device designed for assisted vaginal delivery. It features a soft, flexible cup that creates suction to help deliver the fetus while minimizing scalp trauma. The Omnicup can be used in various fetal positions and is particularly effective in cases where a cephalic presentation is maintained.

c. Fetal Pillow: A soft, inflatable device used to support the fetal head during delivery, particularly in cases of fetal distress. It provides a cushion that can help with positioning and alignment of the fetal head in the birth canal, potentially improving outcomes during labor.

d. C-snorkel: The C-Snorkel is a disposable tube with ventilation ports, intended to release the vacuum between the fetal head and vaginal wall. There are very little data on its use.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Odon device recently introduced device for assisted vaginal birth

questions.text: Single best predictor of successful VBAC is:
questions.solution:
Women with one or more previous vaginal births should be informed that previous vaginal delivery, particularly previous VBAC, is the single best predictor of successful VBAC and is associated with a planned VBAC success rate of 85-90%.

Option-wise Explanation:

a. Previous vaginal delivery:
While a previous vaginal delivery can be a good predictor of successful vaginal birth after caesarean (VBAC), it is not the single best predictor.

c. Bishop score:
The Bishop score helps assess the cervix's readiness for labor but is not the best predictor of VBAC success. While it can indicate the likelihood of a successful vaginal delivery, it is less specific for predicting VBAC success compared to the history of previous VBAC.

d. Maternal BMI:
Maternal BMI can influence pregnancy outcomes, but it is not a direct predictor of VBAC success. Higher BMI may complicate labor and delivery, but it does not specifically indicate the likelihood of a successful VBAC.

KEY TAKEAWAY - The best predictor of successful VBAC is Previous VBAC, as this history directly correlates with higher chances of achieving another successful vaginal delivery after cesarean.

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline No. 45, Birth After Previous Caesarean Birth

choices.text: Cervix is fully dilated and the membranes ruptured
Station at level of ischial spines or below

questions.text: All of the following are prerequisites for assisted vaginal birth, except:
questions.solution:
Head should be </= 1/5 palpable per abdomen. Rest are the deemed prerequisites for assisted vaginal birth.

Here's the option-wise explanation:

b. Cervix is fully dilated and the membranes ruptured

  • Correct: For any assisted vaginal birth, the cervix must be fully dilated (10 cm) and the membranes should have ruptured. This ensures that the fetal head is accessible for instrumentation and there is no obstruction preventing descent.

c. Station at the level of ischial spines or below

  • Correct: The station of the fetal head must be at least at 0 (ischial spines) or lower (+1, +2) for AVD. This indicates that the head has descended enough into the pelvis, making an assisted vaginal delivery feasible.

d. Pelvis is deemed adequate

  • Correct: The maternal pelvis must be deemed adequate for vaginal delivery. This is assessed clinically, ensuring that there are no disproportion issues between the fetal head and the maternal pelvis (cephalopelvic disproportion), which would otherwise lead to failure of an assisted delivery.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: Identify the incision marked by yellow arrow in the following image:
questions.solution:
The Pfannenstiel incision is a transverse skin incision, two finger-breadths above the symphysis pubis, which is extended in the direction of the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and ends 2-3 cm medial to ASIS on both sides.

Usage: Frequently used for C-sections as it offers a strong closure and lower incidence of hernia formation.

Here's a brief definition for each of the incisions:

b. Joel-Cohen Incision

  • Definition: A straight transverse incision made slightly higher than the Pfannenstiel incision, about 3 cm above the pubic symphysis. It involves blunt dissection of the rectus muscles and less tissue trauma.
  • Usage: Known for faster healing and reduced blood loss, often preferred in elective cesarean deliveries.

c. Maylard Incision

  • Definition: A higher transverse incision, cutting through the rectus abdominis muscles, often located above the usual Pfannenstiel incision. It requires cutting the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • Usage: Used when greater access to the pelvis is required, such as in gynecological cancer surgeries.

d. Kerr's Incision

  • Definition: A low transverse uterine incision, commonly used during cesarean sections. It involves a horizontal cut on the lower uterine segment.
  • Usage: This incision reduces the risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies, making it the most preferred method for cesarean sections.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: Which of the following type of uterine incision is associated with the highest risk of rupture in subsequent pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Risk of rupture: Highest in T-shaped.

A T-shaped incision involves a combination of a low transverse incision with a vertical extension into the upper uterine segment. This configuration creates a weak point where the vertical and horizontal incisions intersect, resulting in the highest risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies.

Here's an optionwise explanation

a. Classical Incision

  • Risk of rupture: High.
  • Explanation: The classical incision is a vertical incision made on the upper segment of the uterus. It is associated with a high risk of rupture in subsequent pregnancies (4-9%).

c. Low Transverse Incision

  • Risk of rupture: Low.
  • Explanation: This is the most commonly used incision in cesarean sections due to its minimal risk of rupture in subsequent pregnancies (0.5-1%). The low transverse incision is made horizontally in the lower uterine segment, which is less likely to rupture.

d. Low Vertical Incision

  • Risk of rupture: Moderate.
  • Explanation: A vertical incision made in the lower uterine segment carries a moderate risk of rupture (1-7%), higher than low transverse but lower than classical or T-shaped incisions.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

In this case, T-shaped incisions carry the highest risk of rupture in future pregnancies.

choices.text: 3 cm in front of posterior fontanelle
6 cm in front of posterior fontanelle
5 cm in front of posterior fontanelle

questions.text: A senior resident asked the 2nd year resident posted in labour room to deliver a young primigravida with severe anemia using ventouse. Now, she specifically instructed to position the vacuum cup on the fetal skull at the "Flexion point". What is the location of this flexion point on the fetal skull:
questions.solution:
• The flexion point is found along the sagittal suture, approximately 3 cm from the posterior fontanelle's center and approximately 6 cm from the anterior fontanelle's center.
  • The term flexion point refers to a spot on the fetal head on which the cup of a ventouse should to be placed for extraction of the child to be most effective.
  • When the cup of the ventouse is applied on the flexion point, the fetal head will remain flexed under traction, hence the name flexion point.

KEY TAKEAWAY:
